block.p: LONG before Vietnam, the Spanish-American War drove a wedge into the hearts and souls of Americans. To commemorate the war's centenary, ''Militant Metropolis'' will open Wednesday at the New-York Historical Society.

Newspapers, letters, photographs and sheet music tell the story of the yellow journalism that propelled the nation into battle with Spain over its colonies like Cuba; of Cuban insurgents in New York, and soldiers like Theodore Roosevelt.

LONG before Vietnam, the Spanish-American War drove a wedge into the hearts and souls of Americans. To commemorate the war's centenary, ''Militant Metropolis'' will open Wednesday at the New-York Historical Society.

Newspapers, letters, photographs and sheet music tell the story of the yellow journalism that propelled the nation into battle with Spain over its colonies like Cuba; of Cuban insurgents in New York, and soldiers like Theodore Roosevelt.
The photograph here shows the Dauntless, one of the ''filibusters,'' or ships that made clandestine prewar missions to aid the insurgents.
Many other institutions in the region are commemorating the war this spring, including the New York Public Library, the Hispanic Society of America and the Consulate General of Spain in New York.

''Militant Metropolis: New York City and the Spanish-American War 1898,'' Wednesday through July 12; Tuesday through Sunday, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M.; The New-York Historical Society, 2 West 77th Street (at Central Park West); $5, $3 for students and people 65 and older; (212) 873-3400.
